steps: Barium acetate, calcium acetate and tin acetate were added in 2-ethylhexanoic acid in stoichiometric ratio and dissolved by heating the mixture at 80°C until clear solution was obtained.
The desired stoichiometric quantity of C16H36O4Ti was mixed in the same solvent in separate beaker and then added to the previous solution.
The final solution was then stirred and mixed for 1 h under continuous heating at temperature 80°C.
Finally, the solution was dried so as to obtain BCST powder.
The BCST powder was calcined at temperature 1000°C for 4 h in muffle furnace.
The calcined powder was grinded in mortar pestle with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) solution until fine powder was obtained.
The pellets of the grinded powder were prepared by compressing under 5 ton pressure.
Finally, the pellets were sintered at two different temperatures 1100 and 1200°C for 5 h in order to get densified BCST ceramics samples.
characterization_techniques: PE Loop test system (20PE 1 kHz, Marine India)

steps: Weighing sodium acetate, strontium acetate, bismuth acetate, and barium acetate according to the stoichiometric ratio
Adding the weighed precursors to solvents
Stirring the mixture at 80°C for one hour to obtain the precursor solution
Adjusting the solution concentration to 0.4 mol/L
Depositing the precursor solution on pretreated Pt/TiO2/SiO2/Si substrates by spin coating
Rotating the substrate at 1500 r/min for 10 s and then 3000 r/min for 40 s
Placing the deposited film in a rapid thermal treatment (RTP) furnace for heat treatment
Pyrolysis at 150°C for 3 min to evaporate the solvent
Pyrolysis at 410°C for 10 min to remove organic components
Annealing at 725°C for 3 min for crystallization
Repeating the deposition and heating procedures 6 times
Preparing Au electrodes on the surface of thin films by DC sputtering

steps: Weighing each powder in stoichiometric ratio
Wet milling for 24 hours in ethanol medium using polyethylene bottles containing zirconia balls stabilized with yttria
Drying in an oven at 80°C overnight
Calcining at 1200°C for 4 hours in a zirconia crucible
Pelletizing into disc-shaped samples using a 5 wt.% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder
Sintering at 1450°C for 4 hours at a heating rate of 2°C per minute
Polishing the sintered pellets on silicon carbide paper
Coating with silver paint on both sides and drying for 30 minutes at 600°C

d33 meter Berlincourt meter (PiezoMeter System PM 300, Piezotest Pte Ltd.)

article_metadata.title: Machine learning assisted innovative strategy for experimental validation of functional properties of lead-free ceramics

steps: Mixing stoichiometric ratios of high-purity precursors
Grinding in a mortar and pestle for 2 h
Milling in an ethanol solution with zirconia balls in a low-energy ball mill for 4 h
Drying the resulting solution
Pulverizing the obtained lumps
Calcining at 1200 °C for 4 h in air
Regrinding the resulting granulated powders
Molding into disk-shaped pellets with 1 wt % polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as an organic binder
Heating the pellets at 650 °C for 1 h at a rate of 1 °C per minute to burn off the PVA binder
Sintering the binder-free pellets at 1400 °C for 4 h in air

steps: Mixing 1 g colemanite, 80 mg Fe2O3, 500 mg BaCO3, and 500 mg TiO2
Ball milling the mixture for 15 h at 300 rpm
Adding 2 mL of 13.8 M ammonia solution to the mixture and ball milling for an additional 3 min
Transferring the mixture onto a silicon carbide plate and evaporating the ammonia solution at 150 °C
Heating the SiC plate in a tubular furnace at 1300 °C for 3 h under NH3 gas flow
Stopping NH3 gas flow at 975 °C and cooling to room temperature

steps: Weighing raw materials according to nominal composition
Ball mixing for 24 h with anhydrous ethanol and zirconia balls
Drying the mixed slurries
Calcining at 800 °C for 3 h
Ball milling for 24 h again
Granulating with polyvinyl alcohol solution (PVA, 5 wt%)
Pressing into green pellets under a pressure of 120 ± 10 MPa
Firing at 650 °C for 3 h to burn off PVA
Sintering at 1065 °C–1105 °C for 3 h in air with 5 °C/min followed by furnace-cooling to ambient temperature
